div1.p: The writer suggests field work instead of lab work.

div1.head: Letter fragment to [s.n.] Thurlow, January 8, 1915
div1.p:
In the matter of fish--or rather minnows--to control mosquito
breeding: LePrince and myself have both been interested in the prob-
lem for some time and he makes athe point that a good deal of work may
be done with advantage on this problem, some of which he purposes for
the ensuing season. He makes a point, which is unquestionably true,
that it is field work in fishes rather than laboratory work that is
needed. That it is not which fish can eat the most larvae in a glass bowl, but which
do best control mosquito breeding under specialnatural conditions in specialdifferent
localities and climates. The top minnow, for instance, that is so
universal and so efficient in the tide-water of North Carolina and
South Carolina, is absolutely not found--and nothing found to replace
him--in the up-country of those states, as at Roanoke Rapids and
Goldsborough, N. C. and Rock Hill and Greenville, S. C. I think--and
I strongly underscore “think”--that they probably cannot live in the
swift streams of the up-lands, as I found the same form, and doing
good work, in some ponds there.

LePrince suggests that the striped minnows found in the pond up
the Waxahatchie above the steel bridge would almost certainly be the
fish for your pond as under the same conditions of locality, character
of water, floatage of leaves and of pine needles which prevail at your
pond they were absolutely efficient in controlling the mosquito breeding
